Definition / general

* Specialized immune response against various inflammatory insults, involving chronic activation and organization of mononuclear phagocytic cells (macrophages) ([J Clin Tuberc Other Mycobact Dis 2017;7:1](31723695))* Histologically characterized by epithelioid histiocytes, with or without central necrosis, surrounded by acute or chronic inflammation

Essential features

* Specialized inflammatory response against various offending entities, including ([StatPearls: Granuloma [Accessed 13 June 2022]](32119473)):
  + Infectious (usually necrotic, suppurative)+ Autoimmune / inflammatory+ Malignancy+ Others (see below)* Histologically characterized by central epithelioid histiocytes surrounded by acute or chronic inflammation* Microbiologic cultures of fresh sample, special stains / immunohistochemistry for microorganisms are essential when clinical history includes suspicion of infection or an immunocompromised / suppressed state* Immunohistochemistry to evaluate for malignancies that arise as differential diagnoses (e.g., carcinoma [cytokeratin], melanoma [SOX10]) ([O'Malley: Benign and Reactive Conditions of Lymph Node and Spleen, 1st Edition, 2009](http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/1933477067/pathologyoutl-20))

Terminology

* Lymphadenitis (LA), infectious lymphadenitis, granulomatous lymphadenitis (GLA)

ICD coding

* ICD-10:
  + [I88.1](https://icd10cmtool.cdc.gov/?fy=FY2022&query=I88.1) - chronic or subacute lymphadenitis+ [I88.8](https://icd10cmtool.cdc.gov/?fy=FY2022&query=I88.8) - granuloma, gland (lymph)+ [I88.9](https://icd10cmtool.cdc.gov/?fy=FY2022&query=I88.9) - lymphadenitis+ [L04.9](https://icd10cmtool.cdc.gov/?fy=FY2022&query=L04.9) - acute lymphadenitis+ [D86.1](https://icd10cmtool.cdc.gov/?fy=FY2022&query=D86.1) - sarcoidosis of lymph nodes

Epidemiology

* May be associated with infectious disease or noninfectious disease ([J Clin Tuberc Other Mycobact Dis 2017;7:1](31723695))* No particular predilection for age / sex ([StatPearls: Lymphadenopathy [Accessed 13 June 2022]](32644344))

Sites

* Any lymph node site in the body* Spleen ([O'Malley: Benign and Reactive Conditions of Lymph Node and Spleen, 1st Edition, 2009](http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/1933477067/pathologyoutl-20))* Certain etiologies have strong association with anatomical site ([J Clin Tuberc Other Mycobact Dis 2017;7:1](31723695))
      + Inguinal nodes in lymphogranuloma venereum+ Cervical and axillary nodes in tularemia and cat scratch disease+ Mesenteric lymph nodes in *Yersinia* lymphadenitis+ Pulmonary hilar lymph nodes in environmental, fungal, tuberculous lymphadenitis

Pathophysiology

* Dysregulation of immune response due to inability of macrophages to clear the offending agent ([StatPearls: Granuloma [Accessed 13 June 2022]](32119473))* Results in chronic active inflammation, histologically characterized by ([StatPearls: Granuloma [Accessed 13 June 2022]](32119473)):
    + Central collection of epithelioid histiocytes+ Rim of plasma cells and lymphocytes+ Central necrosis or suppuration, depending on etiology* Can be conceptualized as consisting of 3 phases ([J Clin Exp Hematop 2012;52:1](22706525)):
      + Initiation / accumulation, peak and late phase+ Initiation characterized by activation of T cells via MHC class II interactions with antigen presenting cells (APCs) ([J Clin Tuberc Other Mycobact Dis 2017;7:1](31723695))
          - Activated T helper 1 (Th1) cells stimulate and recruit macrophages via secretion of TNF alpha, IFN gamma, IL2, IL12 and chemokines+ Precise mechanism of defective downregulation of active inflammation is poorly understood+ With ensuing active inflammation, peak phase is characterized by rim of chronic inflammatory infiltrate consisting of:
              - CD4+ T cells, CD8+ T cells, NK cells, plasma cells and occasional granulocytes- Certain infectious GLA features prominent monocytoid B cell infiltrates (*Toxoplasma* lymphadenitis, *Bartonella*) ([J Clin Exp Hematop 2012;52:1](22706525))
                  * Role poorly understood+ Late phase characterized by fibrosis and hyalinization* Resolution occurs after clearance of antigenic stimulus and is characterized by a fibrous scar

Etiology

* Infectious:
  + Suppurative (purulent):
    - Tularemia lymphadenitis (*Francisella tularensis*)- Cat scratch lymphadenitis (*Bartonella henselae*)- *Yersinia* lymphadenitis (*Yersinia enterocolitica*)- Various fungal infections+ Nonsuppurative:
      - Tuberculous lymphadenitis (*Mycobacterium tuberculosis* spp.)- Atypical mycobacterial infection- Bacillus Calmette-Guérin (BCG) lymphadenitis- *Toxoplasma* lymphadenitis- Hansen disease or leprosy (*M. leprae*)- Syphilis- Brucellosis- Fungal lymphadenitis (*Coccidioides*, *Cryptococcus*, *Histoplasma*, *Pneumocystis*)* Noninfectious:
    + Systemic sarcoidosis+ Foreign body (berylliosis, silicosis)+ Malignancies (lymphoma, carcinoma, especially breast, uterus, lung, stomach)+ Systemic inflammatory / autoimmune conditions (lupus [SLE], rheumatoid arthritis [RA], granulomatosis with polyangiitis [GPA])+ Toxic (chemotherapy, heavy metals, beryllium, zirconium, silicon)+ Histiocytic inflammatory (Rosai-Dorfman disease, Castleman disease)* Reference: [J Clin Tuberc Other Mycobact Dis 2017;7:1](31723695)

Clinical features

* Painful / painless lymphadenopathy ([StatPearls: Lymphadenopathy [Accessed 13 June 2022]](32644344))

Diagnosis

* Clinical exam* Imaging:
    + CT+ Ultrasound* Tissue biopsy:
      + Excisional preferred over needle core biopsies, due to preservation of lymph node architecture; usually yields sufficient tissue to perform ancillary studies (microbiologic studies, special stains, immunostains)* Fine needle aspiration (FNA):
        + Can be ultrasound guided* Reference: [StatPearls: Lymphadenopathy [Accessed 13 June 2022]](32644344)

Laboratory

* Dependent on suspected etiology but generally includes:
  + Microbiologic studies (e.g., cultures, serology)
    - Essential to obtain tissue cultures, as necrotic node usually contains high density of organisms+ Autoimmune / rheumatology workupReference: [StatPearls: Lymphadenopathy [Accessed 13 June 2022]](32644344)

Prognostic factors

* Dependent on etiology (e.g., HIV, sarcoidosis, malignancy, infection)

Case reports

* 27 year old Greek man with suppurative necrotizing granulomatous lymphadenitis in adult onset Still disease ([J Med Case Rep 2012;6:354](23078628))* 29 year old man with necrotizing granulomatous sarcoidosis ([Cureus 2020;12:e10220](33042665))* 82 year old man with necrotizing granulomatous lymphadenitis ([BMJ Case Rep 2011;2011:bcr1120103548](22715187))

Treatment

* Management of underlying disease (e.g., infection, neoplasm, inflammatory / autoimmune)* Removal of offending agent (e.g., removal of foreign body)

Gross description

* Pale tan circumscribed nodules* Fibrotic and firm compared to surrounding lymph node parenchyma* Can show central necrosis, which can be dry and crumbly (caseating) or soft with a gelatinous consistency* Can show gross suppuration* Reference: [Foucar: Tumors of the Bone Marrow, 1st Edition, 2016](http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/1933477350/pathologyoutl-20)

Gross images

Frozen section description

* See [Gross description](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/lymphnodesgranulomatous.html#graninflammationgross)

Microscopic (histologic) description

* Collection of epithelioid macrophages with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm and indistinct cell borders ([StatPearls: Granuloma [Accessed 13 June 2022]](32119473))* Surrounded by a rim of inflammatory cells, including lymphocytes, plasma cells and macrophages ([StatPearls: Granuloma [Accessed 13 June 2022]](32119473))* Multinucleated giant cells are often present ([StatPearls: Granuloma [Accessed 13 June 2022]](32119473))* Certain etiologies may demonstrate characteristic features
        + May present as a characteristic triad of florid follicular hyperplasia, interfollicular monocytoid B cells and cortical / subcortical, ill defined aggregates of epithelioid cells (*Toxoplasma* lymphadenitis)* Subtypes:
          + Necrotizing granulomas ([J Clin Exp Hematop 2012;52:1](22706525)):
            - Necrotic focus surrounded by a rim of chronic inflammatory cells, including epithelioid macrophages- May show suppuration (acute inflammation) depending on etiology- Usually associated with infectious agents (e.g., tuberculosis, lymphogranuloma venereum, tularemia, cat scratch disease, fungal)
                  * Important to look for organisms within granulomas* Use special stains to highlight* Often essential for diagnosis as serology may have low sensitivity / specificity* Obtain tissue culture+ Nonnecrotizing (sarcoid and sarcoid-like) granulomas ([J Clin Exp Hematop 2012;52:1](22706525)):
              - Well defined borders, cohesive solid appearance, no central necrosis- Various types of inclusions inside macrophages (e.g., asteroid bodies)- Etiology includes
                    * Sarcoidosis containing Langhans type giant cells containing nuclei arranged in a horseshoe shape along cell periphery* Systemic / autoimmune entities* Foreign body type lymphadenitis containing giant cells with haphazardly arranged nuclei and engulfed foreign material- Lipogranuloma ([O'Malley: Benign and Reactive Conditions of Lymph Node and Spleen, 1st Edition, 2009](http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/1933477067/pathologyoutl-20)):
                      * Frequently found in spleen; can be seen in lymph node* Focus of macrophages with ingested fat surrounded by a rim of lymphocytes and plasma cells* Etiology is unknown* Has been associated with excessive topical application / ingestion of mineral oils

Cytology description

* Sarcoid granulomatous lymphadenitis:
  + Tight collection of epithelioid histiocytes in syncytial arrangement with curved nuclei in horseshoe, C or V shape* Infectious type granulomatous lymphadenitis:
    + Histiocyte cluster may be loose or tight+ Usually surrounded by abundant acute inflammation+ Can show suppuration or necrosis, depending on infectious etiology* Ultimately, findings are nonspecific and microbiologic, serologic studies are needed for a definitive etiology* Reference: [Cibas: Cytology - Diagnostic Principles and Clinical Correlates, 5th Edition, 2020](http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/0323636365/pathologyoutl-20)

Positive stains

* [CD68](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/cdmarkerscd68.html), [CD163](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/cdmarkerscd160.html#cd163), [lysozyme](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainslysozyme.html): highlights epithelioid histiocytes* [CD3](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/cdmarkerscd3.html), [CD20](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/cdmarkerscd20.html): highlights immunoarchitecture; rules out lymphoma

Negative stains

* [Acid fast bacilli (AFB)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsacidfast.html): positive in mycobacterial etiology* [Grocott methenamine silver (GMS)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsgms.html) and [periodic acid-Schiff (PAS)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainspas.html): positive in fungal etiology* [Cytokeratin](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsckgeneral.html): positive in carcinoma* [SOX10](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainssox10.html): positive in melanoma* [CD30](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/cdmarkerscd30.html): positive in Hodgkin lymphoma

Sample pathology report

* R4 lymph node, excision:
  + Nonnecrotizing granulomatous lymphadenitis (see comment)+ No evidence of malignancy identified+ Comment: The overall findings raise the possibility of sarcoidosis; infection remains in the differential diagnosis. AFB and GMS stains are negative for acid fast organisms and fungal forms. Clinical correlation with microbiologic studies is recommended.

Differential diagnosis

* Necrotizing granulomatous inflammation:
  + Suppurative:
    - [Tularemia](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/lymphnodesotherinfections.html#tularemia)- [Cat scratch disease](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/lymphnodescatscratch.html)- [*Yersinia* lymphadenitis](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/lymphnodesotherinfections.html#yersiniapestis)- [Lymphogranuloma venereum](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/lymphnodesotherinfections.html#lymphogranulomavenereum)- [Dematiaceous fungal infection](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/microbiologydematiaceousmolds.html)- [Brucellosis](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/lymphnodesotherinfections.html#brucellosis)- *[Actinomyces](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/lymphnodesotherinfections.html)*+ Nonsuppurative:
      - [Syphilis](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/skinnontumorsyphilis.html)- [Brucellosis](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/lymphnodesotherinfections.html#brucellosis)- Fungal infection (*[Cryptococcus](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/microbiologycneoformans.html)*, *[Histoplasma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/microbiologyhcapsulatum.html)*, [coccidiomycosis](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/lymphnodesotherinfections.html#coccidioides), *[Pneumocystis](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/lungnontumorPCP.html)*, *[Aspergillus](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/lungnontumoraspergillosis.html)*, [*Blastomyces*](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/microbiologyblastomyces.html), [Mucorales](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/nasalmucor.html))- [*Mycobacterium tuberculosis*](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/lymphnodesotherinfections.html#tuberculosis)- [Nontuberculous mycobacteria](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/lymphnodesatypicalmycobacteria.html)- [*Nocardia*](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/microbiologynocardia.html)- [*Yersinia* lymphadenitis](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/lymphnodesotherinfections.html#yersiniapestis)- [Cat scratch disease](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/lymphnodescatscratch.html)* Nonnecrotizing granulomatous inflammation:
    + [*Mycobacterium tuberculosis*](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/lymphnodesotherinfections.html#tuberculosis)+ [Nontuberculous mycobacterium](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/lymphnodesatypicalmycobacteria.html) (including [Hansen disease](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/skinnontumorleprosy.html))+ [*Salmonella* typhi](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/spleenuncommoninfections.html#typhoidfever)+ ***Rickettsia* spp.**+ ***Coxiella***+ ***C. albicans***+ ***C. immitis***+ Viral ([cytomegalovirus](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/colonCMV.html), [herpes](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/lymphnodesotherinfections.html#herpes), **hepatitides**)+ Parasitic ([toxoplasmosis](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/lymphnodestoxoplasma.html), [schistosomiasis](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/parasitologyschisto.html))* Noninfectious:
      + Most noninfectious causes of granulomatous lymphadenitis present with nonnecrotizing granulomatous inflammation, including
        - Autoimmune:
          * [Sarcoidosis](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/lungnontumorsarcoidosis.html)* **Vasculitides*** [Crohn's disease](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/coloncrohns.html)* [Systemic lupus erythematosus](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/lymphnodessle.html)* [Rheumatoid arthritis](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/lymphnodesrheumatoidarthritis.html)- Drugs:
            * **Bacillus Calmette-Guérin*** **NSAIDs*** **Antibiotics*** [Methotrexate](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/liverdrugtoxinmethotrexate.html)- Malignancy associated:
              * **Carcinoma*** **Melanoma*** **Lymphoma** (e.g., [classic Hodgkin lymphoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/lymphomanonBclassic.html), [T cell lymphoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/lymphomanonBperipheral.html))* Foreign body:
        + [Talc, starch, suture, hyaluronic acid (and other injectable fillers)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/lungnontumorivda.html):
          - Foreign material may be visualized within granuloma- May be polarizable* Reactive conditions that present with granulomatous lymphadenitis:
          + [Kikuchi-Fujimoto disease](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/lymphnodeskikuchi.html):
            - Predominance of [CD8](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/cdmarkerscd8.html)+ T cells surrounding necrotic center- Histiocytes with C shaped nuclei- Plasmacytoid dendritic cells+ [Kimura disease](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/lymphnodeskimurasdisease.html):
              - Hypereosinophilia and eosinophilic abscesses- Preservation of follicles, hyperplastic follicles- Stromal and perivascular sclerosis* [Rosai-Dorfman disease](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/lymphnodessinushistiocytosiswithmassivelymph.html) (also known as sinus histiocytosis with massive lymphadenopathy):
            + Histiocytes show abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm, central vesicular nucleus and prominent nucleolus+ Histiocytosis is accompanied by small lymphocytes and plasma cells+ Histiocytes are [S100](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainss100.html)+, [CD1a](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/cdmarkerscd1a.html)-* Histiocytic neoplasms:
              + [Histiocytic sarcoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/lymphnodeshistiocyticsarcoma.html):
                - Rarely affects lymph nodes (usually extranodal presentation)- Diffuse infiltration by malignant, variably pleomorphic, mature appearing histiocytes- Nodal architecture effacement, sparing of follicles- No well formed granulomas+ [Langerhans cell histiocytosis](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/lymphnodesLCH.html):
                  - Lesional cells show prominent nuclear grooves, admixed eosinophils- Positive for [S100](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainss100.html), [CD99](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/cdmarkerscd99.html), [CD1a](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/cdmarkerscd1a.html), [langerin](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/cdmarkerscd200.html#cd207)* Reference: [J Clin Tuberc Other Mycobact Dis 2017;7:1](31723695)
